awd_titl_txt: Assessing the influence of lithology on the temporal-spatial variability of sediment transport and its relation to primary production in mountain streams
awd_abstract_narration:
Primary production provides the fundamental source of energy for most life on earth, and therefore understanding what controls primary production is key to understanding ecosystems. In streams, relevant research has focused mainly on the influence of light and nutrients. The role of underlying geology and sediment transport has not been as well explored. The algae that dominate primary producers in headwater streams live on rocks. Flow events that mobilize those rocks can scrape algae away and reset the system to low production levels. Understanding controls on the frequency of sediment scour and abrasion in a stream is therefore fundamental to understanding the dynamics of primary production. This research project will contribute to a better understanding of the coevolution of ecosystems and landscapes.

This interdisciplinary research project links fluvial geomorphology and stream ecology. The goal is to determine: (a) how spatial variability in velocity and shear stress affect sediment transport in gravel-bedded streams, (b) how these affect primary productivity at reach and patch scale, and (c) what control underlying bedrock lithology exerts on these processes. This project will couple the use of a 2D model and the collection of field measurements in four sites in the Oregon Coast Range. The sites have been selected based on similar climate, light, nutrients, and temperature, but different lithology to isolate the controls it exerts. The project is led by an early career Hispanic female investigator. Collaboration with a local high school will provide a research experience for teachers and involve Native American high school students.

por.por_cntn:
Primary production provides the fundamental source of energy for most life on earth, and therefore understanding what controls primary production is key to understanding ecosystems.  In streams, relevant research has focused on the influence of light and nutrients, but the role of underlying geology and sediment transport has not been well explored. The goal of this research was to determine how spatial variability in velocity and flow forces affect the movement of different sediment grain size fractions, and how these movement events affect stream primary productivity in gravel-bed systems at multiple temporal and spatial scales. We worked in small mountain streams. First working in Oak Creek we combined high resolution information in flow velocity, sediment size, and chlorophyll a—extracted from the algae living attached to the rocks—we found that variations in flow velocity explained half of the variance in chlorophyll a, but the history of disturbance also played an important role.  Algae attached to rocks in areas of low velocity were less susceptible to scour during moderate disturbance events but were slower to recover when scour occurred. In contrast, areas of high velocity responded rapidly to flood events with rapid declines, but also recovered more quickly and appeared to have high potential for maximum accrual of algae. After completing study, we were curios to understand in more detail the effect of geology and sediment size in primary production.  We know that large flows in rivers can disturbed streams ecosystems affecting rates of primary production (PP) by the algae and ecosystem respiration (ER). Underlying lithology can control sediment size, amount, and evolution in the stream, influencing substrate stability and in turn algae living attached to the substrate. We assessed patterns of disturbance and recovery of PP and ER associated with periods of increased flow and suspended sediment in the wet season two streams in the Oregon Coast Range with differing lithologies (volcanic and sedimentary). Post-storm GPP decreased in both streams, but the volcanic basin had greater proportional decreases and recovered slower than the sedimentary basin. This result was unexpected and appears to be associated with lower light availability in the volcanic basin driven by increased turbidity during storm events; the coarser basalt substrate weathers into smaller size fractions than the finer sandstone substrate, remaining in suspension over longer periods and limiting light availability to benthic primary producers. Overall, our results indicated that the underlying lithology of small mountain streams can drive variability in GPP by controlling sediment size and light availability during storms events.  

With this project we were able to develop, pilot, revise, and share a stream physics unit design for high school students.  Through our initial development and piloting with Siletz Valley High School we were able to revise the unit to share it more broadly with a statewide network of rural STEM teachers through the SMILE program at a workshop held in August 2019.  At this workshop teachers received professional development on the stream physics unit so they could pilot the lessons with their students in various stream sites in Oregon.
